THE SECRETARY OP STATE POR AIR agreed that some increase should be made in the emoluments of junior officers.He thought it would be helpful if promotion from pilotofficer to flying officer could take place after 6 months',instead of 12 months', service. Consideration might also begiven to the grant of increased allowances for marriedofficers with children. It was also felt as a grievance thatwhen married officers were posted to stations where they uadto live apart from their families, the allowances which they received in .respect of their families was reduced.In the R.A.F. there was little or no pressure forincreased pay for other ranks. If, however, any increases were granted to officers, it would be necessary to give someincreases to the men. He would be disposed to suggest anincrease in basic rates, starting at 1/- a day for the lowestranks and tapering off to 6d. a day for sergeants.. THE FIRST LORD OP THE ADMIRALTY said that there was little pressure for increased pay for naval ratings. His mainanxiety concerned the junior officers, on whose behalf he hadalready submitted to the Treasury, He had not^.however, had an opportunity of going into these matters indetail before the meeting, and he was not in a position toexpress any final vie^'.THE CHANCELLOR OP THE EXCHEQUER recalled the courseof the discussions leading up to the increases granted inFebruary, 1942; and stressed thefact that, when thoseconcessions were made, it had been comtemplated that nofurther increases would be granted for some considerable timeto come. The only material change in circumstances had beenthe arrival of some, and the impending arrival of very many more, U,S. troops in this country. It was true that thiswould throw into prominence the great disparity between british and American rates of pay. But, whatever increaseswe made, we could not hope to compete with American rates.It had been suggested that arrangements should be made forsome substantial part of the pay of American soldiers to beretained in the United States. Discussion with the U.S.Ambassador had shown that there was little hope of gettingthis done by means of any compulsory arrangements; butexperience had shown that a high proportion of the american troops in Northern Ireland were, in practice, arranging fora substantial part of their pay to be retained in the UnitedStates for the benefit of their dependants. arrangements were also being concerted with the American militaryauthorities to mitigate some of the effects of the disparity between British and American rates of pay - e. g. by the issueof U. S, Army orders prohibiting American troops from buyingin the United Kingdom articles which were in short'supply.He had taken certain steps to test the strengthof feeling on this subject in the House of Commons. his conclusion was that, in the main, this was an agitationengineered by a small number of Members", who were not "lifcelyto command any large Volume of support.The case , or increases was based mainly on the agitation in the Press and the unsettling effect this was having on men in the Services.- He asked whether this was asufficient ground on which to base increases involvingsubstantial expenditure, which would in all probabilityinvolve a continuing commitment for some time after theend of the war.,
